title: Julian Assange denied delay to US extradition hearing
text:
Assange and his legal team had requested a longer period to submit evidence in the case | Jack Taylor/Getty Images Julian Assange denied delay to US extradition hearing Wikileaks founder faces being sent to US over allegations he conspired to break into a Pentagon computer.

A request by Wikileaks founder Julian Assange to delay a court hearing on whether he should be extradited to the United States was denied on Monday.

Assange and his legal team had requested a longer period to submit evidence in the case. But a judge in London refused the request, telling Assange that the next preliminary hearing will take place as planned on December 19 with a full extradition hearing in February, the Guardian reported.

When asked by the judge, Vanessa Baraitser, if he understood what was happening in court, Assange said: “Not really. I can’t think properly. I don’t understand how this is equitable. This superpower had 10 years to prepare for this case and I can’t access my writings. It’s very difficult where I am to do anything, but these people have unlimited resources."

Mark Sommers, Assange's lawyer, claimed the U.S. had been spying on Assange. “This is part of an avowed war on whistleblowers to include investigative journalists and publishers,” Sommers said. “The American state has been actively engaged in intruding on privileged discussions between Mr. Assange and his lawyer.”

Assange faces extradition to the U.S. over allegations he conspired to break into a Pentagon computer. He faces 17 charges of spying and one of computer hacking.
description: Wikileaks founder faces being sent to US over allegations he conspired to break into a Pentagon computer.
